   Assessment and Plan
   78F HTN, CVA c R hemiplegia, PVD, bipolar d/o admitted with
   acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI, PNA
   with increasingly productive cough, on NPPV much of the time.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Acute on chronic. Suspect
   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection. Continues to have radiographic e/o PNA on CXR.
   Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission. No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p
   tracheostomy in [**4-/2096**] [**2-1**] incarcerated hernia repair and failure to
   wean. Unclear if aspiration risk but on po diet at NS.  Ammonia level
   has come down since stopping depakote.  Failed S&S test.
   - Follow ABG
   - Continue linezolid/aztreonam for total of [**10-13**] days
   - Venturi FM/ Intermittent BIPAP
   -  Lasix 20 mg IV today
   - OOB to chair
   - PFTs and negative inspiratory force as out-patient to evaluate
   respiratory muscle function.
   - F/U culture
   - Continue noninvasive ventilation as needed
   - Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care
   # Nutritional Status:  Failed speech and swallow and has refused
   Dobhoff/PEG.  Discussed TPN, however this is not an effective bridge to
   a definitive therapy.
   -  Have speech evaluate Monday
   - Continue to discuss with family
   # Atrial Fibrilation: new AF v. PVCs on [**3-10**]. No history of AF per
   documentation. On IV dilt 10 q6 if HR>160 prn.  Was given lopressor ,
   however may have contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE
   negative.  TSH normal
   - Continue diuresis
   - Give diltiazem IV prn for tachycardia, avoid beta blocker as may have
   worsened her resp. status
   - cycle cardiac enzymes--
 negative X3
   # Lethargy/AMS:  Pt. more disoriented after getting low dose of Ativan
   for agitation overnight [**3-10**].  Present work-up notable for +UA (with
   history of Cipro-R E.coli) and CXR which appears more volume
   over-loaded than true PNA.  Afebrile, without leukocytosis.  Family
   notes h/o coughing.  Could also consider aspiration, viral vs
   atypicals.  Also with hypercarbia that is definitely contributing.
   Resolved with improvement in respiratory status.
   - DC ativan and added to allergy list
   - On nasal cannula now. Mental status much improved
   - Will start  home risperdal dose given occasional anxiety
   - Holding depakote given MS changes and elevated ammonia level
   - Ammonia level normalized now. Suspect adverse effect from Depakote
   - Monitor with serial ABGs
   # UTI/HEMATURIA: ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine, initially
   thought [**2-1**] to simple UTI but given volume concerning for other
   process. No clots. Denying complaints. h/o Cipro-R ecoli.
   - defer more extensive w/u to outpatient provided pt remains stable
   - will defer urology c/s at this time
   - continue Aztreo/Linezolid
   - intermittent irrigation as needed
   - QD hct checks
   - f/u urine cx
   - Outpatient urology w/u
   # Low urine output
 Improved on Lasix
   - Continue Lasix with goal of -500cc today.
   # RASH: likely drug reaction, back appears somewhat more red in
   dependent areas
   - Appears to be improving clinically
   - continue to monitor and consider derm consult if worsening
   # Hypertension: On Diltiazem as outpatient, currently being held given
   pressures.
   - Holding Dilt, but can restart if Pt tachycardic or hypertensive
   - Can give 10 IV hydralazine q6h for HTN
   # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient known chronic venous stasis
   changes & Proteus wound infections.
    - Monitor, lotion [**Hospital1 **]
   # Bipolar disorder: On Risperdal / Depakote as outpatient.
    - Hold medications for AMS, plan to restart as able.
    - Check Depakote level; holding risperdal and depakote.
   # Diverticulosis: Patient h/o LGIB in [**2104**].  No c/o of pain at this
   time to indicate inflammation.
    - No e/o bleeding at this time
    - Continue bowel regimen
    - Monitor Hct
   # s/p CVA: Unclear what deficit remains and patient unable to provide
   further history.  Per family, unable to move R arm and not ambulatory
    - Extensive Neuro exam once patient less lethargic
   # Urinary Incontinence: At baseline.
    - Foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, diurese, replete electrolytes, NPO
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   Access: PIV, A Line, PICC

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of hypertension, chronic venous stasis changes, and Proteus wound infections. She was admitted to the ICU with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure, probable UTI, and pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is stable, with no evidence of PE on CTA. She has a tracheostomy in place and is receiving non-invasive ventilation. Her ammonia level has decreased since stopping Depakote, and she has failed a speech and swallow test.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure may progress to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation.
2. UTI/HEMATURIA: The patient's ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine may indicate a more severe underlying condition, such as a urinary tract infection or kidney stones.
3. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen, requiring further medication adjustments.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's new-onset atrial fibrillation may require further monitoring and treatment.
5. Lethargy/AMS: The patient's lethargy and altered mental status may be related to her underlying medical conditions or medications, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. RASH: The patient's rash may be related to a drug reaction or an underlying skin condition, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
7. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient's chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections may worsen, requiring further treatment and management.
8. Diverticulosis: The patient's history of LGIB may indicate a risk for further bleeding, requiring further monitoring and treatment.
9. s/p CVA: The patient's unclear deficit and inability to provide further history may require further evaluation and treatment.
10. Urinary incontinence: The patient's urinary incontinence may require further evaluation and treatment.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue non-invasive ventilation and monitor for signs of respiratory failure.
2. Continue antibiotic therapy for UTI/HEMATURIA and monitor for signs of infection.
3. Monitor the patient's hypertension and adjust medication as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and adjust medication as necessary.
5. Evaluate the patient's lethargy and altered mental status and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's rash and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's peripheral vascular disease and adjust treatment as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's diverticulosis and adjust treatment as necessary.
9. Evaluate the patient's s/p CVA and adjust treatment as necessary.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's urinary incontinence and adjust treatment as necessary.

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and her disposition is ICU pending clinical improvement.

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old female admitted to the ICU with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure, probable UTI, and PNA. She has a history of CVA, PVD, and bipolar disorder. She is currently receiving NPPV and antibiotics for her respiratory and urinary infections. Her laboratory results show elevated WBC count, HCT, and K+, as well as decreased Cr and TCO2 levels. She has a rash and is experiencing hypotension, hypertension, and tachycardia. She is also experiencing lethargy and altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she requires ongoing management with NPPV and antibiotics.
2. UTI: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis and organ failure due to her UTI.
3. PNA: The patient's PNA is worsening, and she requires ongoing management with antibiotics and respiratory support.
4. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure is likely to continue, and she requires ongoing management with NPPV and antibiotics.
5. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is not well-controlled, and she requires ongoing management with antihypertensive medications.
6. Lethargy and Altered Mental Status: The patient's lethargy and altered mental status are concerning, and she requires ongoing management with sedation and analgesia.
7. RASH: The patient's rash is concerning, and she requires ongoing management with topical treatments and monitoring.
8. Low Urine Output: The patient's low urine output is concerning, and she requires ongoing management with fluid replacement and diuretics.
9. Peripheral Vascular Disease: The patient's PVD is a risk factor for further complications, and she requires ongoing management with anticoagulation and compression stockings.
10. Diverticulosis: The patient's diverticulosis is a risk factor for further complications, and she requires ongoing management with bowel regimen and monitoring.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust her NPPV and antibiotics as necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's UTI and PNA with antibiotics and respiratory support.
3. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust her antihypertensive medications as necessary.
4. Continue to manage the patient's lethargy and altered mental status with sedation and analgesia.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's rash and adjust her treatment as necessary.
6. Continue to manage the patient's low urine output with fluid replacement and diuretics.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's PVD and adjust her anticoagulation and compression stockings as necessary.
8. Continue to manage the patient's diverticulosis with bowel regimen and monitoring.
9. Consider consulting with a pulmonologist and infectious disease specialist for further management of the patient's respiratory and urinary infections.
10. Consider consulting with a nephrologist for further management of the patient's kidney function.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of hypertension, chronic venous stasis changes, Proteus wound infections, and bipolar disorder. She was admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable urinary tract infection (UTI). 

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient remains intubated and is receiving non-invasive ventilation. Her oxygen saturation is 95% on nasal cannula.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which is being managed with IV diltiazem. Her blood pressure is 115/71 mmHg.
* Neurological status: The patient is lethargic and disoriented, but her mental status has improved since discontinuing Ativan.
* Renal status: The patient has ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine, which is being managed with intermittent irrigation. Her urine output has improved with Lasix.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has a Foley catheter in place and is receiving bowel regimen.
* Hematological status: The patient has a low hemoglobin level of 11.5 g/dL and a platelet count of 123 K/uL.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and she may require further interventions to manage her hypercarbic respiratory failure.
* UTI/Pyelonephritis: The patient's UTI is ongoing, and there is a risk of progression to pyelonephritis.
* Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure remains elevated, and there is a risk of complications such as cardiac failure or cerebral bleeding.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to complications such as stroke or cardiac failure.
* Lethargy/AMS: The patient's lethargy and disorientation may worsen, leading to complications such as falls or aspiration.
* Nutritional status: The patient's nutritional status is compromised, and there is a risk of further deterioration if not managed properly.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of diverticulosis and may be at risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Infection: The patient has a Foley catheter and is receiving antibiotics, which may increase her risk of infection.
* Hematological complications: The patient's low hemoglobin level and platelet count may lead to complications such as anemia or bleeding.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing non-invasive ventilation and oxygen therapy
* Managing atrial fibrillation with IV diltiazem
* Monitoring and managing UTI/Pyelonephritis
* Managing hypertension with diuresis and antihypertensive medications
* Monitoring and managing neurological status
* Managing gastrointestinal status with bowel regimen
* Monitoring and managing hematological status
* Continuing to discuss goals of care with the patient and her family.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a complex medical history. Over the past 24 hours, they have undergone various diagnostic tests and treatments. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4C, heart rate of 114 bpm, and blood pressure of 115/71 mmHg. They are receiving respiratory support with nasal cannula oxygen and have a SpO2 of 95%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring is stable, with a fluid balance of 2,340 mL and a blood product transfusion of 1,430 mL.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 6.0 K/uL, hemoglobin of 11.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 123 K/uL. Their electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level. The patient's blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are within normal limits.

The patient has a history of allergies to ciprofloxacin, penicillins, and percocet, and has developed rash and delirium with meropenem and ativan, respectively. They have also developed hyperammonia with depakote.

Potential medical complications:

1. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient has been diagnosed with DVT and is receiving prophylactic heparin sodium. Close monitoring of the patient's clotting status and potential bleeding complications is necessary.
2. Stress ulcer: The patient's history of stress ulcer and recent use of antacids may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding. Close monitoring of the patient's gastrointestinal status and prompt treatment of any bleeding episodes is necessary.
3. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged use of mechanical ventilation increases the risk of VAP. Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status and prompt treatment of any suspected infections is necessary.
4. Hyperammonia: The patient's history of hyperammonia with depakote and recent use of anticonvulsants may increase the risk of further hyperammonia. Close monitoring of the patient's liver function and potential treatment of hyperammonia is necessary.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's slightly elevated potassium level and potential use of diuretics may increase the risk of electrolyte imbalance. Close monitoring of the patient's electrolyte levels and potential treatment of any imbalances is necessary.
6. Infection: The patient's prolonged use of antibiotics and recent use of anticonvulsants may increase the risk of infection. Close monitoring of the patient's infection status and prompt treatment of any suspected infections is necessary.
7. Bleeding complications: The patient's use of anticoagulants and potential bleeding complications may increase the risk of bleeding. Close monitoring of the patient's bleeding status and prompt treatment of any bleeding episodes is necessary.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical history and multiple potential medical complications. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and potential medical complications is necessary to ensure optimal care and prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   78F HTN, CVA c R hemiplegia, PVD, bipolar d/o admitted with
   acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI, PNA
   with increasingly productive cough, on NPPV much of the time.
   # Atrial Fibrilation: new AF. No history of AF per documentation. On IV
   dilt 10 q6 if HR>160 pr.  Was given lopressor , however may have
   contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE negative.  TSH normal.
   Got diltiazem 10mg IV
   - Starting diltiazem drip titrated to HR <110, SBP >80
   - EKG
   - Transition to PO diltiazem pending passing speech and swallow
   evaluation today.
   - Given history of strokes, will discuss anticoagulation; holding off
   now because may get PEG
   .
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Acute on chronic. Suspect
   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection. Continues to have radiographic e/o PNA on CXR.
   Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission. No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p
   tracheostomy in [**4-/2096**] [**2-1**] incarcerated hernia repair and failure to
   wean. Unclear if aspiration risk but on po diet at NS.  Ammonia level
   has come down since stopping depakote.  Failed S&S test.
   - Continue linezolid/aztreonam for total of [**10-13**] days
   - Continue NC as needed, maintain O2 sat > 92%
   - Acquire ABG based on worsening mental status and O2 sat <92%, CO2 <90
   - Lasix 20mg IV x1 today, follow UOP for goal euvolemic
   - PFTs and negative inspiratory force as out-patient to evaluate
   respiratory muscle function.
   - F/U culture
   - Continue noninvasive ventilation as needed
   - Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care
   # Nutritional Status:  Failed speech and swallow and has refused
   Dobhoff/PEG.  Discussed TPN, however this is not an effective bridge to
   a definitive therapy.
   -  Speech and swallow evaluation today
   - Continue to discuss with family
   # Lethargy/AMS:  At baseline today. Agitated, anxious overnight.
   Present work-up notable for +UA (with history of Cipro-R E.coli) and
   CXR which appears more volume over-loaded than true PNA.  Afebrile,
   without leukocytosis.  Family notes h/o coughing.  Could also consider
   aspiration, viral vs atypicals.  Also with hypercarbia that is
   definitely contributing. Resolved with improvement in respiratory
   status.
   - Continue Zydis; will not give Ativan.
   - Will start  home risperdal dose given occasional anxiety
   - Holding depakote given MS changes and elevated ammonia level
   - Ammonia level normalized now. Suspect adverse effect from Depakote
   - Monitor with serial ABGs
   # UTI/HEMATURIA: Hematuria improved. Ongoing moderately high blood loss
   in urine, initially thought [**2-1**] to simple UTI but given volume
   concerning for other process. No clots. Denying complaints. h/o Cipro-R
   ecoli.
   - defer more extensive w/u to outpatient provided pt remains stable
   - continue Aztreo/Linezolid
   - intermittent irrigation as needed
   - QD hct checks
   - f/u urine cx
   - Outpatient urology w/u
   # Low urine output
 Improved on Lasix
   - Continue Lasix with goal of -500cc today.
   # RASH: likely drug reaction, back appears somewhat more red in
   dependent areas
   - Appears to be improving clinically
   - continue to monitor and consider derm consult if worsening
   # Hypertension: On Diltiazem as outpatient, currently being held given
   pressures.
   - Holding Dilt, but can restart if Pt tachycardic or hypertensive
   - Can give 10 IV hydralazine q6h for HTN
   # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient known chronic venous stasis
   changes & Proteus wound infections.
    - Monitor, lotion [**Hospital1 **]
   # Bipolar disorder: On Risperdal / Depakote as outpatient.
    - Hold medications for AMS, plan to restart as able.
    - Check Depakote level; holding risperdal and depakote.
   # Diverticulosis: Patient h/o LGIB in [**2104**].  No c/o of pain at this
   time to indicate inflammation.
    - No e/o bleeding at this time
    - Continue bowel regimen
    - Monitor Hct
   # s/p CVA: Unclear what deficit remains and patient unable to provide
   further history.  Per family, unable to move R arm and not ambulatory
    - Extensive Neuro exam once patient less lethargic
   # Urinary Incontinence: At baseline.
    - Foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, diurese, replete electrolytes, NPO

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of hypertension, CVA with right hemiplegia, peripheral vascular disease, and bipolar disorder. She was admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable urinary tract infection (UTI). The patient has been experiencing atrial fibrillation, which is new and not previously documented. She has also been experiencing lethargy and altered mental status, which has resolved with improvement in respiratory status.

The patient has undergone various interventions, including non-invasive ventilation, antibiotics, and diuretics. She has also been started on IV diltiazem for rate control and has had a speech and swallow evaluation, which was failed. The patient has refused Dobhoff/PEG tube and has been discussed for total parenteral nutrition (TPN), but this is not considered an effective bridge to definitive therapy.

The patient has several potential complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure is multifactorial and may be exacerbated by her atrial fibrillation, chronic hypercarbia, and infection.
2. UTI: The patient's hematuria has improved, but she still has ongoing moderately high blood loss in her urine, which may be concerning for another process.
3. Lethargy/AMS: The patient's altered mental status may be related to her hypercarbia, infection, or other factors.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is being managed with IV diltiazem, but she may require further antihypertensive therapy.
5. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient's chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections may be contributing to her overall poor condition.
6. Bipolar disorder: The patient's bipolar disorder is being managed with Risperdal and Depakote, but these medications may need to be adjusted or discontinued due to her altered mental status.

Based on this information, I identify potential medical complications that may arise, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure may progress and require more aggressive interventions, such as mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's UTI and ongoing blood loss in her urine may lead to sepsis, which could have serious consequences.
3. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and hypertension may increase her risk of cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction or stroke.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's chronic diverticulosis and history of LGIB may increase her risk of gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's CVA and altered mental status may increase her risk of further neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires careful monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve her overall outcome.

   dilt 10 q6 if HR>160 pr.  Was given lopressor , however may have
   contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE negative.  TSH normal.

   - EKG
   - Transition to PO diltiazem pending passing speech and swallow
   evaluation today.
   - Given history of strokes, will discuss anticoagulation; holding off
   now because may get PEG
   .

   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection. Continues to have radiographic e/o PNA on CXR.
   Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission. No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p

   wean. Unclear if aspiration risk but on po diet at NS.  Ammonia level

   - Continue NC as needed, maintain O2 sat > 92%
   - Acquire ABG based on worsening mental status and O2 sat <92%, CO2 <90
   - Lasix 20mg IV x1 today, follow UOP for goal euvolemic
   - PFTs and negative inspiratory force as out-patient to evaluate
   respiratory muscle function.
   - F/U culture
   - Continue noninvasive ventilation as needed
   - Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care

   Dobhoff/PEG.  Discussed TPN, however this is not an effective bridge to
   a definitive therapy.
   -  Speech and swallow evaluation today

   Present work-up notable for +UA (with history of Cipro-R E.coli) and
   CXR which appears more volume over-loaded than true PNA.  Afebrile,

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of hypertension, CVA with right hemiplegia, PVD, and bipolar disorder, admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI. She has a tracheostomy and is receiving non-invasive ventilation. Her recent lab results show:

* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and neutrophils
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and alkaline phosphatase (ALK PHOS)
* Normal potassium, sodium, and chloride levels
* Elevated glucose level
* Abnormal liver function tests (LFTs) with elevated AST and ALT
* Normal thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level

The patient has several medical conditions, including:

* Atrial fibrillation (AF) with a new onset
* Hypercarbic respiratory failure with acute-on-chronic exacerbation
* Probable urinary tract infection (UTI)
* Hematuria with ongoing moderately high blood loss in urine
* Low urine output
* Rash, likely due to a drug reaction
* Peripheral vascular disease with chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections
* Bipolar disorder
* Diverticulosis with a history of lower gastrointestinal bleeding (LGIB)
* S/p CVA with unclear deficit and unable to provide further history

The patient's current medications include:

* Diltiazem for atrial fibrillation
* Linezolid and aztreonam for UTI
* Lasix for hypercarbic respiratory failure and low urine output
* Risperdal for bipolar disorder
* Depakote for bipolar disorder (held due to elevated ammonia level)
* Hydralazine for hypertension (held due to controlled blood pressure)

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Worsening respiratory status due to hypercarbic respiratory failure
* Development of pneumonia or other secondary infections
* Hemodynamic instability due to atrial fibrillation and hypertension
* Bleeding complications due to hematuria and low platelet count
* Worsening of peripheral vascular disease and chronic venous stasis changes
* Recurrence of urinary tract infection or development of sepsis
* Development of gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to diverticulosis
* Neurological worsening due to CVA and lack of clear deficit assessment

Given the patient's complex medical conditions and multiple medications, it is essential to closely monitor her condition and adjust her treatment plan as needed to prevent complications and ensure optimal care.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current health status as follows:

The patient is a 78-year-old female admitted to the ICU with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure, probable urinary tract infection (UTI), and a history of chronic hypertension, stroke, peripheral vascular disease, and bipolar disorder. She has been experiencing increasing productive cough, tachypnea, and hypoxia. Her respiratory status has been managed with non-invasive ventilation and oxygen therapy.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.4C, heart rate of 114 bpm, and blood pressure of 115/71 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 95% on nasal cannula. Her laboratory results show anemia, mild hyponatremia, and hypercarbia.

The patient has several ongoing medical issues, including:

1. Atrial fibrillation, which is being managed with IV diltiazem.
2. Lethargy/AMS, which has resolved with improvement in respiratory status.
3. UTI, which is being treated with antibiotics.
4. Low urine output, which has improved with Lasix therapy.
5. Rash, which is likely a drug reaction.
6. Hypertension, which is being managed with IV hydralazine.
7. Peripheral vascular disease, which is being monitored.
8. Bipolar disorder, which is being managed with risperdal and depakote, both of which are being held due to AMS.
9. Diverticulosis, which is being managed with a bowel regimen.
10. s/p CVA, which is causing hemiplegia and limited mobility.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she may require further intervention, such as mechanical ventilation.
2. UTI/sepsis: The patient's UTI may progress to sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure.
3. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen, leading to complications such as cardiac failure or stroke.
4. Hypercarbia: The patient's hypercarbia may worsen, leading to respiratory acidosis and other complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to fatigue, shortness of breath, and other complications.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may worsen, leading to seizures, coma, and other complications.
7. Rash: The patient's rash may worsen, leading to further complications.
8. Bipolar disorder: The patient's bipolar disorder may worsen, leading to manic or depressive episodes.
9. Diverticulosis: The patient's diverticulosis may worsen, leading to complications such as bleeding or perforation.
10. s/p CVA: The patient's s/p CVA may worsen, leading to further neurological deficits or complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old female admitted to the ICU with hypercarbic respiratory failure, pneumonia, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (afib/RVR). She has a history of chronic respiratory failure, hypertension, and bipolar disorder. The patient's condition has improved, and she is no longer requiring non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV). However, she continues to experience afib/RVR, which is being managed with intravenous diltiazem and non-invasive blood pressure monitoring.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure may lead to further respiratory compromise, particularly if she experiences a worsening of her afib/RVR.
2. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response: The patient's afib/RVR may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, tachycardia, and potential cardiac arrest.
3. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen if not managed effectively, leading to further cardiac strain and potential complications.
4. Urinary tract infection: The patient's urinary tract infection may progress and lead to sepsis, which could worsen her respiratory and cardiac status.
5. DVT: The patient's history of peripheral vascular disease (PVD) and recent use of unfractionated heparin for prophylaxis may increase her risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
6. Stress ulcer: The patient's critical illness may lead to stress ulceration, particularly if she experiences prolonged periods of mechanical ventilation or has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. VAP: The patient's use of mechanical ventilation and prolonged ICU stay may increase her risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Based on the patient's current condition and medical history, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of her afib/RVR, hypertension, and respiratory status. Additionally, the patient's risk of developing DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP should be closely monitored and managed accordingly.

   78F HTN, CVA c R hemiplegia, PVD, bipolar d/o admitted with
   acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI, PNA
   with productive cough, now significantly improved, completely off NPPV.
   # Atrial Fibrilation: new AF now resolved on dilt gtt. No history of AF
   per documentation. On IV dilt 10 q6 if HR>160 pr.  Was given lopressor
   , however may have contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE
   negative. TSH normal.
   - Starting diltiazem drip titrated to HR <110, SBP >80
   - Transition to PO diltiazem pending passing speech and swallow
   evaluation today.
   - Given history of strokes, will discuss anticoagulation; holding off
   now because may get PEG
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Acute on chronic. Suspect
   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection. Continues to have radiographic e/o PNA on CXR.
   Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission. No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p
   tracheostomy in [**4-/2096**] [**2-1**] incarcerated hernia repair and failure to
   wean. Unclear if aspiration risk but on po diet at NS.  Ammonia level
   has come down since stopping depakote.  Failed S&S test.
   - Continue linezolid/aztreonam for total of [**10-13**] days
   - Continue NC as needed, maintain O2 sat > 92%
   - Acquire ABG based on worsening mental status and O2 sat <92%, CO2 <90
   - Lasix 20mg IV x1 today, follow UOP for goal euvolemic
   - PFTs and negative inspiratory force as out-patient to evaluate
   respiratory muscle function.
   - F/U culture
   - Continue noninvasive ventilation as needed
   - Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care
   # Nutritional Status:  Failed speech and swallow and has refused
   Dobhoff/PEG.  Discussed TPN, however this is not an effective bridge to
   a definitive therapy.
   -  Speech and swallow evaluation today
   - Continue to discuss with family
   # Lethargy/AMS:  At baseline today. Agitated, anxious overnight.
   Present work-up notable for +UA (with history of Cipro-R E.coli) and
   CXR which appears more volume over-loaded than true PNA.  Afebrile,
   without leukocytosis.  Family notes h/o coughing.  Could also consider
   aspiration, viral vs atypicals.  Also with hypercarbia that is
   definitely contributing. Resolved with improvement in respiratory
   status.
   - Continue Zydis; will not give Ativan.
   - Will start  home risperdal dose given occasional anxiety
   - Holding depakote given MS changes and elevated ammonia level
   - Ammonia level normalized now. Suspect adverse effect from Depakote
   - Monitor with serial ABGs
   # UTI/HEMATURIA: Hematuria improved. Ongoing moderately high blood loss
   in urine, initially thought [**2-1**] to simple UTI but given volume
   concerning for other process. No clots. Denying complaints. h/o Cipro-R
   ecoli.
   - defer more extensive w/u to outpatient provided pt remains stable
   - continue Aztreo/Linezolid
   - intermittent irrigation as needed
   - QD hct checks
   - f/u urine cx
   - Outpatient urology w/u
   # Low urine output
 Improved on Lasix
   - Continue Lasix with goal of -500cc today.
   # RASH: likely drug reaction, back appears somewhat more red in
   dependent areas
   - Appears to be improving clinically
   - continue to monitor and consider derm consult if worsening
   # Hypertension: On Diltiazem as outpatient, currently being held given
   pressures.
   - Holding Dilt, but can restart if Pt tachycardic or hypertensive
   - Can give 10 IV hydralazine q6h for HTN
   # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient known chronic venous stasis
   changes & Proteus wound infections.
    - Monitor, lotion [**Hospital1 **]
   # Bipolar disorder: On Risperdal / Depakote as outpatient.
    - Hold medications for AMS, plan to restart as able.
    - Check Depakote level; holding risperdal and depakote.
   # Diverticulosis: Patient h/o LGIB in [**2104**].  No c/o of pain at this
   time to indicate inflammation.
    - No e/o bleeding at this time
    - Continue bowel regimen
    - Monitor Hct
   # s/p CVA: Unclear what deficit remains and patient unable to provide
   further history.  Per family, unable to move R arm and not ambulatory

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of hypertension, CVA with right hemiplegia, PVD, and bipolar disorder, admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI.
* She has been improving significantly, with a resolution of atrial fibrillation and decreased respiratory distress.
* However, she remains at risk for various complications due to her underlying conditions and current medical status.

**Potential Complications:**

1. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and she may experience further deterioration due to her chronic hypercarbia, PNA, and potential aspiration risk.
2. **UTI/Hematuria:** The patient's hematuria has improved, but she still has ongoing moderately high blood loss in her urine, which may indicate a more severe underlying condition.
3. **Low Urine Output:** The patient's urine output has improved with Lasix, but she may still experience further decreases in output due to her underlying conditions.
4. **Hypertension:** The patient's hypertension is currently being managed with Diltiazem, but she may require further treatment to control her blood pressure.
5. **Peripheral Vascular Disease:** The patient's chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections may lead to further complications, such as deep vein thrombosis or infection.
6. **Bipolar Disorder:** The patient's bipolar disorder is currently being managed with Risperdal and Depakote, but she may experience further episodes of mania or depression due to her underlying condition.
7. **Diverticulosis:** The patient's history of LGIB and current diverticulosis may lead to further complications, such as bleeding or infection.
8. **s/p CVA:** The patient's CVA has resulted in significant deficits, including hemiplegia and inability to ambulate, which may lead to further complications, such as pressure ulcers or respiratory failure.
9. **Urinary Incontinence:** The patient's urinary incontinence may lead to further complications, such as urinary tract infections or skin irritation.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent further deterioration.
2. Perform further evaluation of the patient's UTI and hematuria to determine the underlying cause and appropriate treatment.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension with Diltiazem and consider restarting if her blood pressure becomes unstable.
4. Monitor the patient's peripheral vascular disease and wound infections to prevent further complications.
5. Continue to manage the patient's bipolar disorder with Risperdal and Depakote, and consider restarting if her condition worsens.
6. Monitor the patient's diverticulosis and bowel regimen to prevent further complications.
7. Perform an extensive neuro exam to determine the extent of the patient's CVA-related deficits and develop a plan to manage them.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's urinary incontinence and consider further treatment options to manage her symptoms.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's condition remains stable, with some minor fluctuations. The patient has been on nasal canula for oxygen support and has required a steam mask to maintain adequate oxygen saturation. The patient's heart rhythm has been stable, with conversion to sinus rhythm after starting a diltiazem drip.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia (Hct 37.5%) and mild thrombocytopenia (Plt 123). The liver function tests (ALT and AST) are within normal limits, but the alkaline phosphatase level is slightly elevated (57 IU/L). The patient's kidney function is normal, with a creatinine level of 0.3 mg/dL.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 134. The patient's ABG results show a mild respiratory acidosis (pH 7.29).

The patient's infection status is unclear, with a history of antibiotic use (Aztreonam and Linezolid) and an indeterminate speech and swallow evaluation. The patient is NPO pending further evaluation.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: Given the patient's history of respiratory instability and mild respiratory acidosis, there is a risk of respiratory failure if oxygen support is not maintained.
2. Infection: The patient's history of antibiotic use and indeterminate speech and swallow evaluation suggest a risk of infection, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Bleeding: The patient's mild thrombocytopenia (Plt 123) increases the risk of bleeding, particularly with invasive procedures or trauma.
4. Liver dysfunction: The patient's slightly elevated alkaline phosphatase level (57 IU/L) suggests a risk of liver dysfunction, which could lead to coagulopathy and other complications.
5. Kidney dysfunction: The patient's mild anemia (Hct 37.5%) and mild thrombocytopenia (Plt 123) increase the risk of kidney dysfunction, particularly if the patient develops sepsis or other complications.

Given the patient's stable condition and potential medical complications, it is essential to continue monitoring the patient's respiratory status, infection risk, and laboratory results to prevent or promptly address any complications that may arise.

   Assessment and Plan
   78F HTN, CVA c R hemiplegia, PVD, bipolar d/o admitted with
   acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI, PNA
   with increasingly productive cough, on NPPV much of the time.
   # Atrial Fibrilation: new AF now resolved on dilt gtt. No history of AF
   per documentation. On IV dilt 10 q6 if HR>160 pr.  Was given lopressor
   , however may have contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE
   negative. TSH normal.
   - Starting diltiazem drip titrated to HR <110, SBP >80
   - Transition to PO diltiazem pending passing speech and swallow
   evaluation today.
   - Given history of strokes, will discuss anticoagulation; holding off
   now because may get PEG
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Acute on chronic. Suspect
   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection. Continues to have radiographic e/o PNA on CXR.
   Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission. No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p
   tracheostomy in [**4-/2096**] [**2-1**] incarcerated hernia repair and failure to
   wean. Unclear if aspiration risk but on po diet at NS.  Ammonia level
   has come down since stopping depakote.  Failed S&S test.
   - Continue linezolid/aztreonam for total of [**10-13**] days
   - Continue NC as needed, maintain O2 sat > 92%
   - Acquire ABG based on worsening mental status and O2 sat <92%, CO2 <90
   - Lasix 20mg IV x1 today, follow UOP for goal euvolemic
   - PFTs and negative inspiratory force as out-patient to evaluate
   respiratory muscle function.
   - F/U culture
   - Continue noninvasive ventilation as needed
   - Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care
   # Nutritional Status:  Failed speech and swallow and has refused
   Dobhoff/PEG.  Discussed TPN, however this is not an effective bridge to
   a definitive therapy.
   -  Speech and swallow evaluation today
   - Continue to discuss with family
   # Lethargy/AMS:  At baseline today. Agitated, anxious overnight.
   Present work-up notable for +UA (with history of Cipro-R E.coli) and
   CXR which appears more volume over-loaded than true PNA.  Afebrile,
   without leukocytosis.  Family notes h/o coughing.  Could also consider
   aspiration, viral vs atypicals.  Also with hypercarbia that is
   definitely contributing. Resolved with improvement in respiratory
   status.
   - Continue Zydis; will not give Ativan.
   - Will start  home risperdal dose given occasional anxiety
   - Holding depakote given MS changes and elevated ammonia level
   - Ammonia level normalized now. Suspect adverse effect from Depakote
   - Monitor with serial ABGs
   # UTI/HEMATURIA: Hematuria improved. Ongoing moderately high blood loss
   in urine, initially thought [**2-1**] to simple UTI but given volume
   concerning for other process. No clots. Denying complaints. h/o Cipro-R
   ecoli.
   - defer more extensive w/u to outpatient provided pt remains stable
   - continue Aztreo/Linezolid
   - intermittent irrigation as needed
   - QD hct checks
   - f/u urine cx
   - Outpatient urology w/u
   # Low urine output
 Improved on Lasix
   - Continue Lasix with goal of -500cc today.
   # RASH: likely drug reaction, back appears somewhat more red in
   dependent areas
   - Appears to be improving clinically
   - continue to monitor and consider derm consult if worsening
   # Hypertension: On Diltiazem as outpatient, currently being held given
   pressures.
   - Holding Dilt, but can restart if Pt tachycardic or hypertensive
   - Can give 10 IV hydralazine q6h for HTN
   # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient known chronic venous stasis
   changes & Proteus wound infections.
    - Monitor, lotion [**Hospital1 **]
   # Bipolar disorder: On Risperdal / Depakote as outpatient.
    - Hold medications for AMS, plan to restart as able.
    - Check Depakote level; holding risperdal and depakote.
   # Diverticulosis: Patient h/o LGIB in [**2104**].  No c/o of pain at this
   time to indicate inflammation.
    - No e/o bleeding at this time
    - Continue bowel regimen
    - Monitor Hct
   # s/p CVA: Unclear what deficit remains and patient unable to provide
   further history.  Per family, unable to move R arm and not ambulatory
    - Extensive Neuro exam once patient less lethargic
   # Urinary Incontinence: At baseline.
    - Foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, diurese, replete electrolytes, NPO
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin

   , however may have contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE
   negative. TSH normal.

   - Transition to PO diltiazem pending passing speech and swallow

   Dobhoff/PEG.  Discussed TPN, however this is not an effective bridge to
   a definitive therapy.
   -  Speech and swallow evaluation today

   Present work-up notable for +UA (with history of Cipro-R E.coli) and

   without leukocytosis.  Family notes h/o coughing.  Could also consider
   aspiration, viral vs atypicals.  Also with hypercarbia that is
   definitely contributing. Resolved with improvement in respiratory
   status.

   - Holding depakote given MS changes and elevated ammonia level

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current health status as follows:

The patient, an 78-year-old woman, is admitted to the ICU with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure, probable urinary tract infection (UTI), and pneumonia (PNA). She has a history of hypertension, chronic venous stasis changes, and Proteus wound infections. She is also known to have a left-sided hemiplegia due to a previous cerebrovascular accident (CVA).

Currently, the patient is experiencing dryness and desaturation, requiring a steam mask to maintain oxygen saturation above 92%. Her heart rhythm is in sinus rhythm, and she has a history of atrial fibrillation, which has resolved with treatment.

The patient has failed a speech and swallow evaluation and has refused a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube. She is NPO pending further evaluation.

Her laboratory results show mild anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated creatinine levels. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals a pH of 7.29, indicating hypercarbia. Her white blood cell count is within normal limits, but her differential shows a shift towards neutrophils.

The patient's medication list includes diltiazem, linezolid, aztreonam, and lasix, among others. She has a history of adverse reactions to certain medications, including ciprofloxacin and depakote.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing hypercarbic respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed.
2. UTI: The patient's UTI may progress to a more severe infection if not effectively treated.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's PNA may worsen if not properly managed.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may worsen if not properly managed.
5. Anemia: The patient's mild anemia may worsen if not properly managed.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen if not properly managed.
7. Hypercarbia: The patient's hypercarbia may worsen if not properly managed.
8. Adverse reactions to medications: The patient's history of adverse reactions to certain medications may increase the risk of further adverse reactions.

Based on the patient's current health status and potential medical complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.
2. Continue to treat the patient's UTI and PNA with antibiotics and other appropriate therapies.
3. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.
5. Monitor the patient's hypercarbia and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.
6. Avoid certain medications that may exacerbate the patient's adverse reactions.
7. Consider consulting with a specialist, such as a pulmonologist or a nephrologist, to further evaluate and manage the patient's respiratory and kidney function.
8. Consider performing further diagnostic tests, such as a CT scan or a pulmonary function test, to further evaluate the patient's respiratory status.

   Assessment and Plan
   78F HTN, CVA c R hemiplegia, PVD, bipolar d/o admitted with
   acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI, PNA
   with productive cough, now significantly improved, completely off NPPV.
   # Atrial Fibrilation: new AF now resolved on dilt gtt. No history of AF
   per documentation. On IV dilt 10 q6 if HR>160 pr.  Was given lopressor
   , however may have contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE
   negative. TSH normal.
   - Started diltiazem drip titrated to HR <110, SBP >80. Will titrate to
   IV dilt today, and PO if tolerating PO meds
   - Transition to PO diltiazem pending passing speech and swallow
   evaluation today.
   - Given history of strokes, will discuss anticoagulation; holding off
   now because may get PEG
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Acute on chronic. Suspect
   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection. Continues to have radiographic e/o PNA on CXR.
   Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission. No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p
   tracheostomy in [**4-/2096**] [**2-1**] incarcerated hernia repair and failure to
   wean. Unclear if aspiration risk but on po diet at NS.  Ammonia level
   has come down since stopping depakote.  Failed S&S test.
   - Continue linezolid/aztreonam for total of [**10-13**] days
   - Continue NC as needed, maintain O2 sat > 92%
   - Acquire ABG based on worsening mental status and O2 sat <92%, CO2 <90
   - Lasix 20mg IV x1 today, follow UOP for goal euvolemic
   - PFTs and negative inspiratory force as out-patient to evaluate
   respiratory muscle function.
   - F/U culture
   - Continue noninvasive ventilation as needed
   - Social work consult and family meeting to discuss goals of care
   # Nutritional Status:  Failed speech and swallow and has refused
   Dobhoff/PEG.  Discussed TPN, however this is not an effective bridge to
   a definitive therapy.
   -  Speech and swallow evaluation today
   - Continue to discuss with family
   # Lethargy/AMS:  At baseline today. Agitated, anxious overnight.
   Present work-up notable for +UA (with history of Cipro-R E.coli) and
   CXR which appears more volume over-loaded than true PNA.  Afebrile,
   without leukocytosis.  Family notes h/o coughing.  Could also consider
   aspiration, viral vs atypicals.  Also with hypercarbia that is
   definitely contributing. Resolved with improvement in respiratory
   status.
   - Continue Zydis; will not give Ativan.
   - Will start  home risperdal dose given occasional anxiety
   - Holding depakote given MS changes and elevated ammonia level
   - Ammonia level normalized now. Suspect adverse effect from Depakote
   - Monitor with serial ABGs
   # UTI/HEMATURIA: Hematuria improved. Ongoing moderately high blood loss
   in urine, initially thought [**2-1**] to simple UTI but given volume
   concerning for other process. No clots. Denying complaints. h/o Cipro-R
   ecoli.
   - defer more extensive w/u to outpatient provided pt remains stable
   - continue Aztreo/Linezolid
   - intermittent irrigation as needed
   - QD hct checks
   - f/u urine cx
   - Outpatient urology w/u
   # Low urine output
 Improved on Lasix
   - Continue Lasix with goal of even today.
   # RASH: likely drug reaction, back appears somewhat more red in
   dependent areas
   - Appears to be improving clinically
   - continue to monitor and consider derm consult if worsening
   # Hypertension: On Diltiazem as outpatient, currently being held given
   pressures.
   - Holding Dilt, but can restart if Pt tachycardic or hypertensive
   - Can give 10 IV hydralazine q6h for HTN
   # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient known chronic venous stasis
   changes & Proteus wound infections.
    - Monitor, lotion [**Hospital1 **]
   # Bipolar disorder: On Risperdal / Depakote as outpatient.
    - Hold medications for AMS, plan to restart as able.
    - Check Depakote level; holding risperdal and depakote.
   # Diverticulosis: Patient h/o LGIB in [**2104**].  No c/o of pain at this
   time to indicate inflammation.
    - No e/o bleeding at this time
    - Continue bowel regimen
    - Monitor Hct
   # s/p CVA: Unclear what deficit remains and patient unable to provide
   further history.  Per family, unable to move R arm and not ambulatory
    - Extensive Neuro exam once patient less lethargic
   # Urinary Incontinence: At baseline.
    - Foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, diurese, replete electrolytes, NPO
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   Access: A Line, PICC
   Code: DNR/DNI  (confirmed with patient upon arrival to ICU)
   Communication: Patient & daughter [**Name (NI) 1040**]
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement;, will call out to floor
   today
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female admitted to the ICU with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure in the setting of bilateral lower lobe pneumonia, likely due to aspiration. The patient has a history of chronic respiratory failure, hypertension, CVA with residual right hemiplegia, PVD, and bipolar disorder.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 35.6C, heart rate of 81 beats per minute, blood pressure of 101/42 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on nasal cannula. The patient's electrocardiogram shows sinus rhythm.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, normocephalic head, and soft, non-tender abdomen. The patient has black, hyperkeratotic lesions on both extremities and is somnolent.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 6.0, hemoglobin of 11.1 g/dL, platelet count of 123 K/uL, and creatinine of 0.4 mg/dL. The patient's blood urea nitrogen is 42 mg/dL, and her serum potassium is 4.2 mEq/L.

The patient's respiratory status is impaired, with chronic respiratory failure and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient is also at risk for urinary tract infection due to indwelling urinary catheter.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pneumonia progression: The patient's pneumonia may worsen, leading to sepsis, respiratory failure, or other complications.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure may lead to further deterioration, requiring mechanical ventilation or other interventions.
3. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to embolic events, such as stroke or pulmonary embolism.
4. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia or other infections may lead to sepsis, which can be life-threatening.
5. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels may indicate kidney damage or failure, which can worsen with continued illness.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's indwelling urinary catheter and nasogastric tube may increase the risk of urinary tract infections or gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's somnolence and altered mental status may indicate neurological damage or deterioration, which can be life-threatening.

The patient's plan of care includes continuing antibiotics, attempting to wean IV diltiazem, and performing a video swallow to assess for potential need for a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube. The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and she is currently in the ICU.

   Assessment and Plan
   78F HTN, CVA c R hemiplegia, PVD, bipolar d/o admitted with
   acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI, PNA
   with productive cough, now significantly improved, completely off NPPV.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Acute on chronic. Suspect
   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection. Continues to have radiographic e/o PNA on CXR.
   Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission. No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p
   tracheostomy in 5/99 [**2-1**] incarcerated hernia repair and failure to
   wean. Now s/p linezolid/aztreonam.
   - Continue NC as needed, maintain O2 sat in low 90s
   - Acquire ABG based on worsening mental status and O2 sat <92%, CO2 <90
   # Nutritional Status: Failed video speech and swallow. Pt amenable to
   PEG but not any oral or nasal tube.
    - Finalize plans with family at meeting today
   - page speech prior to meeting as they can be involved to comment on
   the studies done
    - No TPN for now
   # Lethargy/AMS: Mostly now at baseline, occasionally agitated at times.
   Original AMS likely multifactorial including infectious, hypercarbic.
   Now resolved. Ammonia level has come down since stopping depakote.
   - Continue Zydis; will not give Ativan.
   - Continue home risperdal dose given occasional anxiety
   - Continue to hold depakote given MS changes and elevated ammonia level
   # Atrial Fibrilation: new AF now resolved. No history of AF per
   documentation. Off of IV Diltiazem drip.  Was given lopressor , however
   may have contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE negative. TSH
   normal.
   - Would ideally rate control her with PO meds
 revisit this once PEG
   placed
   - Given history of strokes, will discuss anticoagulation; holding off
   now because may get PEG
   [image004.jpg]
   # UTI/Hematuria: Hematuria had improved, but now continues.  Completed
   antibiotic course.  Likely needs outpatient follow up for work up of
   possible urinary malignancy
   - continue to monitor
   - f/u urine cytology
   # Low urine output: Intermittent, generally improved on Lasix, but
   overall not staying even.
   -          Goal is even today
 will not diurese
   [image006.jpg]
   [image008.jpg]
   # Rash: resolved. Was likely drug reaction with mild erythematous rash
   across chest and back. Likely drug reaction thought most likely to
   meropenem, which was added to her allergy list.
   # Hypertension: On diltiazem as outpatient, was on dilt gtt inpatient,
   now off.
   - restart PO dilt once feeding tube resolved
   - Can give 10 IV hydralazine q6h for HTN
   # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient known chronic venous stasis
   changes & Proteus wound infections.
    - Monitor, lotion [**Hospital1 **]
   # Bipolar disorder: On Risperdal / Depakote as outpatient, now off
   depakote (added to allergies due to concern for high ammonia levels).
   Restarted risperdal. Using Zydis (SL zyprexa) prn.
   # Diverticulosis: Patient h/o LGIB in [**2104**].  No c/o of pain at this

    - Continue bowel regimen
    - Monitor Hct

Based on the progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 78-year-old female with a history of hypertension, chronic venous stasis changes, Proteus wound infections, bipolar disorder, diverticulosis, and a history of cerebrovascular accident (CVA) with residual deficits. She was admitted to the ICU with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable urinary tract infection (UTI).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.8C, heart rate of 85 bpm, and blood pressure of 124/55 mmHg. She is receiving oxygen therapy through a nasal cannula and has a SpO2 of 89%. Her respiratory status has improved significantly, and she is no longer intubated.

The patient's laboratory results show that she has a white blood cell count of 5.1, hemoglobin of 11.8 g/dL, and platelet count of 126. Her liver function tests are normal, and her electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

The patient's medical conditions include hypercarbic respiratory failure, UTI, pneumonia, and hypertension. She has a history of atrial fibrillation, which has resolved. She is also experiencing lethargy and agitation, which is thought to be multifactorial.

The patient's treatment plan includes continued non-invasive ventilation, antibiotics for her UTI, and management of her hypertension. She is also being monitored for her respiratory status, and her electrolyte levels are being closely monitored.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure can worsen if her oxygen saturation levels drop below 92%.
2. UTI: The patient's UTI can lead to sepsis and organ failure if not properly treated.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia can worsen if not properly treated, leading to respiratory failure and sepsis.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension can lead to cardiac complications if not properly managed.
5. Lethargy and agitation: The patient's lethargy and agitation can worsen if not properly managed, leading to increased risk of falls and other complications.
6. CVA: The patient's history of CVA increases her risk of stroke recurrence.
7. Urinary incontinence: The patient's urinary incontinence can lead to skin breakdown and other complications if not properly managed.

Overall, the patient's health progress in the ICU is stable, but she requires close monitoring and management of her medical conditions to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old female admitted to the ICU with a history of HAP and completed a course of antibiotics. She is currently on gentle maintenance fluids and has been decannulated. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.8C, heart rate of 85 bpm, and blood pressure of 124/55 mmHg. She is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula and has an SpO2 of 89%. The patient's respiratory support includes a non-rebreather mask with a flow rate of 21 L/min.

The patient's physical examination is significant for a rash on her chest, which appears to be completely resolved. Her abdominal examination is soft, non-tender, and bowel sounds are present. Her neurologic examination is normal, with the patient being attentive, following simple commands, and responding to verbal stimuli.

Laboratory results show:

* WBC: 5.1-6.2 K/uL
* Hct: 37.4-39.5%
* Plt: 126-154 K/uL
* Cr: 0.3-0.4 mg/dL
* TCO2: 42-45 mmHg
* Glucose: 74-86 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT / PTT / INR: 12.6/40.4/1.1, CK / CKMB / Troponin-T: 39/5/<0.01, ALT / AST: 8-17 IU/L, Alk Phos / T Bili: 57/0.3 mg/dL, Differential-Neuts: 72.1%, Band: 0.0%, Lymph: 16.7%, Mono: 8.1%, Eos: 2.9%, Lactic Acid: 0.9 mmol/L, Albumin: 3.0 g/dL, LDH: 252 IU/L, Ca++: 8.4 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.1 mg/dL, PO4: 2.2 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

* Abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) / intraabdominal hypertension (IAH)
* Impaired skin integrity
* Airway clearance, impaired
* Aerobic capacity / endurance, impaired
* Balance, impaired
* Transfers, impaired
* Alteration in nutrition
* Atrial fibrillation (AFIB)
* Urinary tract infection (UTI)
* Respiratory failure, chronic

The patient is at risk for developing ACS/IAH due to her abdominal surgery and presence of IAH. She is also at risk for developing skin integrity issues due to her prolonged hospitalization and presence of a rash. The patient's impaired airway clearance and aerobic capacity/endurance may increase her risk for respiratory failure. Her altered nutrition and presence of UTI may increase her risk for further complications. The patient's atrial fibrillation may increase her risk for stroke and other cardiovascular complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   78F HTN, CVA c R hemiplegia, PVD, bipolar d/o admitted with
   acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI, PNA
   with productive cough, now significantly improved, completely off NPPV.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Acute on chronic. Suspect
   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection. Continues to have radiographic e/o PNA on CXR.
   Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission. No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p
   tracheostomy in [**4-/2096**] [**2-1**] incarcerated hernia repair and failure to
   wean. Now s/p linezolid/aztreonam.
   - Continue NC as needed, maintain O2 sat > 92%
   - Lasix 20mg IV x1 today, follow UOP for goal euvolemic
   - Acquire ABG based on worsening mental status and O2 sat <92%, CO2 <90
   # Nutritional Status: Failed video speech and swallow. Pt amenable to
   PEG but not any oral or nasal tube.
    - Finalize plans with family at meeting today
    - No TPN for now
   # Lethargy/AMS: Mostly now at baseline, occasionally agitated at times.
   Original AMS likely multifactorial including infectious, hypercarbic.
   Now resolved. Ammonia level has come down since stopping depakote.
   - Continue Zydis; will not give Ativan.
   - Continue home risperdal dose given occasional anxiety
   - Continue to hold depakote given MS changes and elevated ammonia level
   # Atrial Fibrilation: new AF now resolved on dilt gtt. No history of AF
   per documentation. On IV dilt 10 q6 if HR>160 pr.  Was given lopressor
   , however may have contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE
   negative. TSH normal.
   - Started diltiazem drip titrated to HR <110, SBP >80. Will titrate to
   IV dilt today, and PO if tolerating PO meds
   - Transition to PO diltiazem pending passing speech and swallow
   evaluation today.
   - Given history of strokes, will discuss anticoagulation; holding off
   now because may get PEG
   [image004.jpg]
   # UTI/Hematuria: Hematuria resolved. Initial concern for other process
   (potential malignancy) given ongoing hematuria but now resolved. Of
   note, pt with h/o Cipro-R ecoli.
   - if returns, outpatient workup by urology would be appropriate
   - continue Aztreo/Linezolid
   - intermittent irrigation as needed
   # Low urine output: Intermittent, generally improved on Lasix, but
   overall not staying even.
   -          Continue Lasix with goal of even today, will likely need [**Hospital1 **]
   dosing
   [image006.jpg]
   [image008.jpg]
   # Rash: resolved. Was likely drug reaction with mild erythematous rash
   across chest and back. Likely drug reaction thought most likely to
   meropenem, which was added to her allergy list.
   # Hypertension: On diltiazem as outpatient, was on dilt gtt inpatient,
   now off.
   - restart PO dilt once feeding tube resolved
   - Can give 10 IV hydralazine q6h for HTN
   # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient known chronic venous stasis
   changes & Proteus wound infections.
    - Monitor, lotion [**Hospital1 **]
   # Bipolar disorder: On Risperdal / Depakote as outpatient, now off
   depakote (added to allergies due to concern for high ammonia levels).
   Restarted risperdal. Using Zydis (SL zyprexa) prn.
   # Diverticulosis: Patient h/o LGIB in [**2104**].  No c/o of pain at this
   time to indicate inflammation.
    - No e/o bleeding at this time
    - Continue bowel regimen
    - Monitor Hct
   # s/p CVA: Unclear what deficit remains and patient unable to provide
   further history.  Per family, unable to move R arm and not ambulatory
    - Extensive Neuro exam once patient less lethargic
   # Urinary Incontinence: At baseline.
    - Foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, diurese, replete electrolytes, NPO pending PEG tube
   placement
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   Access: A Line, PICC
   Code: DNR/DNI  (confirmed with patient upon arrival to ICU)

   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement;, will call out to floor
   today

   Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission. No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p
   tracheostomy in [**4-/2096**] [**2-1**] incarcerated hernia repair and failure to
   wean. Now s/p linezolid/aztreonam.
   - Continue NC as needed, maintain O2 sat > 92%
   - Lasix 20mg IV x1 today, follow UOP for goal euvolemic
   - Acquire ABG based on worsening mental status and O2 sat <92%, CO2 <90
   # Nutritional Status: Failed video speech and swallow. Pt amenable to
   PEG but not any oral or nasal tube.
    - Finalize plans with family at meeting today
    - No TPN for now
   # Lethargy/AMS: Mostly now at baseline, occasionally agitated at times.
   Original AMS likely multifactorial including infectious, hypercarbic.
   Now resolved. Ammonia level has come down since stopping depakote.
   - Continue Zydis; will not give Ativan.
   - Continue home risperdal dose given occasional anxiety
   - Continue to hold depakote given MS changes and elevated ammonia level
   # Atrial Fibrilation: new AF now resolved on dilt gtt. No history of AF
   per documentation. On IV dilt 10 q6 if HR>160 pr.  Was given lopressor
   , however may have contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE
   negative. TSH normal.
   - Started diltiazem drip titrated to HR <110, SBP >80. Will titrate to
   IV dilt today, and PO if tolerating PO meds
   - Transition to PO diltiazem pending passing speech and swallow
   evaluation today.
   - Given history of strokes, will discuss anticoagulation; holding off
   now because may get PEG
   [image004.jpg]
   # UTI/Hematuria: Hematuria resolved. Initial concern for other process
   (potential malignancy) given ongoing hematuria but now resolved. Of

   - if returns, outpatient workup by urology would be appropriate
   - continue Aztreo/Linezolid
   - intermittent irrigation as needed

   now off.

   - Can give 10 IV hydralazine q6h for HTN

    - Continue bowel regimen

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 78-year-old female admitted to the ICU with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure, probable UTI, and PNA with productive cough. She has a history of CVA, PVD, and bipolar disorder. She was previously on NPPV but is now off and has improved significantly.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure can lead to further deterioration in her respiratory status, requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation.
2. UTI/Hematuria: The patient's hematuria has resolved, but if it returns, it may indicate a more serious underlying condition, such as a urinary tract infection or potential malignancy.
3. Low urine output: The patient's intermittent low urine output may indicate a potential problem with her kidneys or other underlying condition.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may require further management, and she may need to restart her outpatient medication.
5. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's new-onset atrial fibrillation has resolved, but she may be at risk for future episodes.
6. Peripheral vascular disease: The patient's chronic venous stasis changes and Proteus wound infections may require ongoing monitoring and treatment.
7. Bipolar disorder: The patient's bipolar disorder may require ongoing management, and she may need to restart her outpatient medication.
8. Diverticulosis: The patient's history of LGIB and diverticulosis may require ongoing monitoring and treatment.
9. S/p CVA: The patient's unclear remaining deficit and inability to provide further history may require further evaluation and management.
10. Urinary incontinence: The patient's urinary incontinence may require ongoing management, and she may need to continue using a Foley catheter.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Continuing NC as needed to maintain O2 sat > 92%.
2. Monitoring her urine output and adjusting her diuretic medication as needed.
3. Acquiring ABG based on worsening mental status and O2 sat <92%.
4. Finalizing plans with family at the meeting today regarding PEG placement.
5. Restarting PO diltiazem once her feeding tube is resolved.
6. Monitoring her electrolytes and adjusting her medication as needed.
7. Continuing to hold depakote due to concerns about high ammonia levels.
8. Monitoring her blood pressure and adjusting her medication as needed.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and ensure her optimal care.

Summary:

The patient is a 78-year-old female admitted with acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure in the setting of BLL pneumonia, probably due to aspiration. She has a history of chronic respiratory failure, hypertension, and bipolar disorder. She is currently receiving treatment for pneumonia with linezolid and aztreonam for 14 days. Her respiratory failure has improved, and she is in sinus rhythm. However, she has several ongoing medical issues, including abdominal compartment syndrome/intraabdominal hypertension, impaired skin integrity, impaired airway clearance, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, and altered nutrition.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure may worsen if she does not receive adequate treatment and management.
2. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome/Intraabdominal Hypertension: This condition can lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not managed promptly and effectively.
3. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's skin integrity may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further complications such as pressure ulcers or infections.
4. Impaired Airway Clearance: The patient's airway clearance may be impaired due to her chronic respiratory failure, which can lead to further respiratory complications.
5. Impaired Aerobic Capacity/Endurance: The patient's impaired aerobic capacity/endurance may make it difficult for her to perform daily activities and may lead to further complications.
6. Altered Nutrition: The patient's altered nutrition may lead to malnutrition, which can worsen her overall health and increase the risk of complications.
7. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): The patient's history of UTI and her current respiratory failure may increase her risk of developing further complications.
8. Atrial Fibrillation (AFIB): The patient's AFIB may increase her risk of developing further cardiac complications.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address her ongoing medical issues and prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   78F HTN, CVA c R hemiplegia, PVD, bipolar d/o admitted with
   acute-on-chronic hypercarbic respiratory failure and probable UTI, PNA
   with productive cough, now significantly improved, completely off NPPV.
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Acute on chronic. Suspect
   multifactorial including chronic hypercarbia at baseline +/- excess
   volume +/- infection. Continues to have radiographic e/o PNA on CXR.
   Baseline HCO3 30, 38 on admission. No evidence of PE on CTA. s/p
   tracheostomy in 5/99 [**2-1**] incarcerated hernia repair and failure to
   wean. Now s/p linezolid/aztreonam.
   - Continue NC as needed, maintain O2 sat in low 90s
   - Acquire ABG based on worsening mental status and O2 sat <92%, CO2 <90
   # Nutritional Status: Failed video speech and swallow. PEG tube planned
   for today vs tomorrow.
   - No TPN for now
   # Anxiety: patient with known history of mental illness with recently
   stopped mood stabilizing medication exhibiting signs of intermittent
   anxiety with tachycardia, tachypnea and distress without clearly
   identifiable other causes and noteably triggered by stressful events
    - psych consult
   # Lethargy/AMS: Mostly now at baseline, occasionally agitated at times.
   Original AMS likely multifactorial including infectious, hypercarbic.
   Now resolved. Ammonia level has come down since stopping depakote.
   - Continue Zydis; will not give Ativan.
   - Continue home risperdal dose given occasional anxiety
   - Continue to hold depakote given MS changes and elevated ammonia level
   # Atrial Fibrilation: new AF now resolved. No history of AF per
   documentation. Off of IV Diltiazem drip.  Was given lopressor , however
   may have contributed to worsening respiratory status. CE negative. TSH
   normal.
   - Would ideally rate control her with PO meds
 revisit this once PEG
   placed
   - Given history of strokes, will discuss anticoagulation; holding off
   now because may get PEG
   # UTI/Hematuria: Hematuria had improved, but now continues. Completed
   antibiotic course.  Likely needs outpatient follow up for work up of
   possible urinary malignancy
   - continue to monitor
   - f/u urine cytology
   # Low urine output: Intermittent, generally improved on Lasix, but
   overall not staying even.
    - Goal is even today
 will not diurese
   # Rash: resolved. Was likely drug reaction with mild erythematous rash
   across chest and back. Likely drug reaction thought most likely to
   meropenem, which was added to her allergy list.
   # Hypertension: On diltiazem as outpatient, was on dilt gtt inpatient,
   now off.
   - restart PO dilt once feeding tube resolved
   - Can give 10 IV hydralazine q6h for HTN
   # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient known chronic venous stasis
   changes & Proteus wound infections.
    - Monitor, lotion [**Hospital1 **]
   # Bipolar disorder: On Risperdal / Depakote as outpatient, now off
   depakote (added to allergies due to concern for high ammonia levels).
   Restarted risperdal. Using Zydis (SL zyprexa) prn.
   # Diverticulosis: Patient h/o LGIB in [**2104**].  No c/o of pain at this
   time to indicate inflammation.
    - No e/o bleeding at this time
    - Continue bowel regimen
    - Monitor Hct
   # s/p CVA: Unclear what deficit remains and patient unable to provide
   further history.  Per family, unable to move R arm and not ambulatory
    - Extensive Neuro exam once patient less lethargic
   # Urinary Incontinence: At baseline.
    - Foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, diurese, replete electrolytes, NPO pending PEG tube
   placement
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   Access: A Line, PICC
   Code: DNR/DNI  (confirmed with patient upon arrival to ICU)

   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement;, will call out to floor
